Always looks for the smallest
tree within the tree

A bonsai tree is a living tree or shrub which has been grown in a way which gives the impression of being a full-sized, mature tree. An artistic representation of a full-sized tree in nature. Bonsai trees are generally grown in shallow ceramic pots.

Bonsai Tree Care for Beginners

How to Position Your Bonsai Tree

To find the perfect location for your bonsai, it's crucial to identify the type of tree you have and its ideal environment. For outdoor bonsai, like juniper and pine, exposure to the seasons is essential, while deciduous trees like elms and maples also thrive outdoors. Indoor bonsai, such as jade and ficus trees, require stable temperatures throughout the year to thrive.

Once you have identified the type of bonsai you have, you can select the best location for it. Outdoor bonsai will need to be placed in areas with appropriate sun exposure and airflow, while indoor bonsai will require a stable environment with indirect sunlight. Proper placement will ensure that your bonsai thrives and brings beauty to your space.

Once you’ve figured out what type of bonsai tree you have, the rest is fairly simple. Here are some general tips on bonsai tree positioning that typically apply to all types of bonsai trees.

  • Positioning: Your bonsai should be kept away from direct heat or draft.
  • Lighting: Keep your bonsai in area with plenty of sunlight.
  • Humidity: Bonsais need humidity in order to keep their soil moist.

Watering Your Bonsai Tree

The primary cause of bonsai tree death is often due to under-watering. Because of the shallow soil layer, it can dry out quickly. To prevent this, it's important to water your bonsai tree as soon as the top layer of soil appears dry. Depending on the size and type of your bonsai tree, watering frequency can vary and may need to be done daily. Therefore, it's essential to water each bonsai plant individually, rather than sticking to a set routine.

Pruning and Shaping Your Bonsai Tree
